fields.description:
After launching a BFEBS instance, the query against the metadata service for block device mapping returns the following:

* curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/root => /dev/sda1
* curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/ephemeral => sda2
* curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/ephemeral0 => sda2
* curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/swap => sda3

This is incorrect.  The available (since this is KVM using virtIO for disk, the prefix of the devices is vd) devices are as follows:

{code}
# fdisk /dev/vda

Command (m for help): p

Disk /dev/vda: 4294 MB, 4294967296 bytes
43 heads, 32 sectors/track, 6096 cylinders, total 8388608 sectors
Units = sectors of 1 * 512 = 512 bytes
Sector size (logical/physical): 512 bytes / 512 bytes
I/O size (minimum/optimal): 512 bytes / 512 bytes
Disk identifier: 0x0005c6e4

   Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System
/dev/vda1            2048     8388607     4193280   83  Linux

# fdisk /dev/vdb
Device contains neither a valid DOS partition table, nor Sun, SGI or OSF disklabel
Building a new DOS disklabel with disk identifier 0xdff94e48.
Changes will remain in memory only, until you decide to write them.
After that, of course, the previous content won't be recoverable.

Warning: invalid flag 0x0000 of partition table 4 will be corrected by w(rite)

Command (m for help): p

Disk /dev/vdb: 10.7 GB, 10737418240 bytes
16 heads, 63 sectors/track, 20805 cylinders, total 20971520 sectors
Units = sectors of 1 * 512 = 512 bytes
Sector size (logical/physical): 512 bytes / 512 bytes
I/O size (minimum/optimal): 512 bytes / 512 bytes
Disk identifier: 0xdff94e48

   Device Boot      Start         End      Blocks   Id  System

Command (m for help):

ls /dev/vd*
/dev/vda  /dev/vda1  /dev/vdb

# curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/
emi
ephemeral
ephemeral0
root
swap
{code}

The /dev/vdb device (which is ephemeral) is a known bug - EUCA-3271.  

In AWS, the same query returns the following:

{code}
$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/
ami
root
{code}

Per the AWS documentation for EBS-backed instances, ephermal and other block devices will show up if they are passed when a user requests them via ec2-register or ec2-run-instances. 

*References*

* http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/block-device-mapping-concepts.html
* http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/Using_LaunchingInstaceFromSnapshot.html
* http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/ApiReference-cmd-RegisterImage.html
* http://docs.amazonwebservices.com/AWSEC2/latest/CommandLineReference/ApiReference-cmd-RunInstances.html
fields.summary: metadata service incorrect for BFEBS instance

comments.body: these values are hard coded in the metadata service today.  This fix won't make it into 3.2.  BE and CLC team to discuss and come up with solution
Chuck to assess this one and provide input.

For reference, please check the following link:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/InstanceStorage.html#InstanceStoreDeviceNames

It has a detailed explanation as to when /dev/sda2 is used for ephemeral storage and when /dev/sdb is used for ephemeral storage.  In short, if the vm.type used for the instance is not m1.small or c1.medium, then /dev/sdb is the ephemeral device.

{code}
/dev/sda2	Formatted and mounted as /mnt or /media/ephemeral0 on m1.small and c1.medium instances.
/dev/sdb	Formatted and mounted as /mnt or /media/ephemeral0 on m1.medium, m1.large, m1.xlarge, c1.xlarge, cc1.4xlarge, cc2.8xlarge, m2.xlarge, m2.2xlarge, m2.4xlarge, and hi1.4xlarge.
{code}

[~hspencer], in this bug you bring up several inconsistencies between Euca and AWS:

* Different format of device strings for 'root' and 'ephemeral': '/dev/sda1' vs 'sda2'
* Not using VirtIO names ('vda' vs 'sda')
* Reporting 'ephemeral', 'ephemeral0', and 'swap' even though '-b' option is not used
* Different definitions of VM types (/dev/sda2 vs /dev/sdb)

Obviously, we'd like to fix them all. But some are easier fixes than others. (I think making VM types more consistent / configurable is a development story for 3.3.) So...

Which specific inconsistency prompted you to file the bug? We can try to prioritize fixing that.
Removing from 3.2.1.  This needs additional investigation and possibly more significant design changes.

[~dmitrii],

Yep, makes sense.  The specific inconsistency that brought this issue up was the different definitions of VM types (/dev/sda2 vs /dev/sdb).  Sorry I wasn't clear on that earlier.  

I agree with you, figuring out how to make the VM types more consistent/configurable is the best way to go about resolving this issue and others. If it helps, I added additional information in EUCA-3954 that discusses the documentation that AWS provides. 

Thanks again for your response on this.  Let me know if you need any additional information.

Regards,

[~hspencer]

Among the several things that need to be fixed to completely resolve this issue, one of the fixes is to replace the hard coded values in the metadata service. What this means is metadata service should reflect the block devices as requested by the user (stored in CLC database) and thereby communicated to NC by CLC. This may or may not be a match to the block device mapping on the VM instance due to hypervisor constraints.  

For instance, if a user registers a bfebs image with /dev/vda as the root device and with kvm as the hypervisor, the metadata service will publish the root device as /dev/vda and the actual root device also happens to be /dev/vda. This wont be the case if the image is registered with /dev/sda as the root device, metadata service returns /dev/sda as the root device while /dev/vda is the actual root device. 

Hardcoded values are being fixed along with/as a part of EUCA-4786 (support multiple ebs mappings)

Hey [~swathi], 

I am not sure if you have had the opportunity to check the behavior on AWS, but the block device mapping is pretty much standard regarding root, swap and ephemeral (This is true for instance-backed and ebs-backed instances).  For example, here is the root device mapping for the metadata service on AWS for instance-backed:

{code}
INSTANCE	i-e5c8c595	ami-0354c36a	ec2-54-234-203-124.compute-1.amazonaws.com	ip-10-151-18-218.ec2.internal	running	hspencer-test	0		m1.small	2013-02-13T18:03:07+0000	us-east-1b	aki-88aa75e1			monitoring-disabled	54.234.203.124	10.151.18.218			instance-store					paravirtual	xen		sg-c09762a8	default	false

ubuntu@ip-10-151-18-218:~$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/root      
/dev/sda1
{code}

But if you look at what device is actually mounted, its the following:

{code}
ubuntu@ip-10-151-18-218:~$ df -ah
Filesystem      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/xvda1      9.9G  809M  8.6G   9% /
proc               0     0     0    - /proc
sysfs              0     0     0    - /sys
none               0     0     0    - /sys/fs/fuse/connections
none               0     0     0    - /sys/kernel/debug
none               0     0     0    - /sys/kernel/security
udev            819M   12K  819M   1% /dev
devpts             0     0     0    - /dev/pts
tmpfs           331M  176K  331M   1% /run
none            5.0M     0  5.0M   0% /run/lock
none            827M     0  827M   0% /run/shm
/dev/xvda2      147G  188M  140G   1% /mnt
{code}

Here is another instance that is EBS-backed

{code}
INSTANCE	i-23cac753	ami-78f16011	ec2-54-234-227-152.compute-1.amazonaws.com	ip-10-110-214-233.ec2.internal	running	hspencer-test	0		m1.small	2013-02-13T18:03:43+0000	us-east-1b	aki-88aa75e1			monitoring-disabled	54.234.227.152	10.110.214.233			ebs					paravirtual	xen		sg-c09762a8	default	false	
BLOCKDEVICE	/dev/sda1	vol-e4cfbc95	2013-02-13T18:03:47.000Z	true
{code}

{code}
ubuntu@ip-10-110-214-233:~$ df -ah
Filesystem      Size  Used Avail Use% Mounted on
/dev/xvda1      7.9G  912M  6.6G  12% /
proc               0     0     0    - /proc
sysfs              0     0     0    - /sys
none               0     0     0    - /sys/fs/fuse/connections
none               0     0     0    - /sys/kernel/debug
none               0     0     0    - /sys/kernel/security
udev            819M  8.0K  819M   1% /dev
devpts             0     0     0    - /dev/pts
tmpfs           331M  176K  331M   1% /run
none            5.0M     0  5.0M   0% /run/lock
none            827M     0  827M   0% /run/shm
/dev/xvdb       147G  188M  140G   1% /mnt
{code}

{code}
ubuntu@ip-10-110-214-233:~$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/root
/dev/sda1

ubuntu@ip-10-110-214-233:~$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/ephemeral0
sdb
{code}

As you can see, even if the metadata supplies sd*, the instance makes sure that the appropriate device is mounted. This is something that AWS users are already familiar with.  For folks who haven't used AWS, this is an education opportunity. 

My point here is this - there is joint education that needs to be done here:

1) What Eucalyptus is doing in regards to block device mapping

2) What Cloud Users can do with regards to getting the behavior they want using udev rules, etc.  (an example of this can be found here - https://github.com/eucalyptus/Eucalyptus-Scripts/blob/master/euca-udev and https://github.com/eucalyptus/Eucalyptus-Scripts/blob/master/euca-udev.rules)

I think what would be really helpful, is after this has been fixed if we could provide some documentation - similar along the lines of the following example:

* http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/block-device-mapping-concepts.html

This way, for example, we can start coming up with more udev rules in our images, and start educating users on how to create their own udev rules, etc.  If the behavior is understood, then we can provide supporting docs.  Thoughts?

[~hspencer]: I've been testing metadata service for ebs backed instances in AWS and found things to be inconsistent. For instance:

* root option was not listed for an ebs backed instance with an additional ebs volume. But it was listed when I launched the instance with no additional ebs volumes
* there never is a swap option under block-device-mappings metadata 
* ebs metadata is indexed as ebs1, ebs2 and so on. ebs1 is always skipped, any additional ebs volumes are listed as ebs2. The root ebs volume is not listed under ebs metadata. 

I've been looking through the ec2 documentation for some explanation about metadata service behavior but couldn't find anything that describes what I found out while testing. Please let me know if you come across any document thats talks about this.  

I completely agree with you about providing more documentation to our customers. I'm hoping that we'll introduce a boat load of documentation when we fix EUCA-4786 and will cover metadata service too in there.

Hey [~swathi],

I did a bit of digging and found this link that may help answer your questions:

http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/AESDG-chapter-instancedata.html#instancedata-data-categories

I think this article answers your questions as follows:

{code}
* root option was not listed for an ebs backed instance with
an additional ebs volume. But it was listed when I launched the
instance with no additional ebs volumes
{code}

block-device-mapping/ebsN	The virtual devices associated with Amazon EBS volumes, if any are present. _Only available in metadata if it is present at launch time_. N indicates the index of the Amazon EBS volume (such as ebs1, ebs2, etc.).

{code}
* there never is a swap option under block-device-mappings metadata
{code}

IMO, this makes sense.  When you are launching EBS-backed instance, there isn't a need to define a swap.  This is something that is mostly seen in instance-backed instances.

block-device-mapping/swap	The virtual devices associated with swap. Not always present.

{code}
* ebs metadata is indexed as ebs1, ebs2 and so on. ebs1 is always skipped,
any additional ebs volumes are listed as ebs2. The root ebs volume is not
listed under ebs metadata.
{code}

This question somewhat confuses me.  I did the following tests - 

*First Test*

* Launched EBS-backed instance on AWS using the following parameters (using Ubuntu 12.04 Precise cloud image with one EBS volume): 
{code}
$ ec2-run-instances -k hspencer-test -b "/dev/sdh=:20" -b
"/dev/sdb=ephemeral0" --user-data-file cloud-init.config ami-78f16011
{code}

* Did a query on the metadata service to see what block devices were available:
{code}
$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/
ami
ebs1
ephemeral0
root
swap
{code}

* Did a query against the ebs1 entry and saw the following:
{code}
$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/ebs1
sdh
{code}

*Second Test*

* Launched EBS-backed instance on AWS using the following parameters (using Ubuntu 12.04 Precise cloud image with two EBS volume):
{code}
$ ec2-run-instances -k hspencer-test -b "/dev/sdh=:20" 
-b "/dev/sdi=:10" --user-data-file cloud-init.config ami-78f16011
{code}

* Did a query on the metadata service to see what block devices were available:
{code}
$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/
ami
ebs1
ebs2
ephemeral0
root
swap
{code}

* Did a query against the ebs1 and ebs2 entries and saw the following:
{code}
$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/ebs1
sdh

$ curl http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/block-device-mapping/ebs2
sdi
{code}

Was this not what you experienced?  Would you mind sharing your test case?  IMO, the behavior from my test case makes sense.  I think this speaks to the behavior mentioned in the link above, found under the "block-device-mapping/ebsN" description:

block-device-mapping/ebsN	The virtual devices associated with Amazon EBS volumes, if any are present. _Only available in metadata if it is present at launch time_. N indicates the index of the Amazon EBS volume (such as ebs1, ebs2, etc.).

The reason that I think that the root device doesn't show up under the block-device-mapping/ebsN is because I _think_ AWS treats these EBS volumes passed at launch similar to how ephemeral can be chopped up when you launch an instance-backed instance, except it doesn't limit you based upon what VM type you have in order to take advantage of having multiple ephemeral devices. *NOTE* Only certain VM types allow multiple ephemeral for instance-backed instances - check the following resources for more information:

* http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/InstanceStorage.html#InstanceStoreDeviceNames
* http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AWSEC2/latest/UserGuide/block-device-mapping-concepts.html#ami-block-device-mapping - see the following line:
{code}
To attach an additional instance store volume, /dev/sdc, use this option. If the instance type doesnt support more than one instance store volume, this option has no effect.

b "/dev/sdc=ephemeral1"
{code}

Does that make sense?  

Regarding the proper devices being passed appropriately to the instance when its launched, I am wondering if this is something that can be addressed jointly by work done on the NC (hypervisor), and work done in the kernel modules for KVM in the instance? (I think this is how Xen is able to guarantee the device mapping).  Maybe we could leverage the Image Management team in the community to help with figuring this out.  Thoughts?

Thanks for putting in work on this.  Let me know if this helps.  

Cheers,

Harold Spencer, Jr.

*Update*

[~swathi], I did a bit of searching and it seems the block device mapping to specific targets should be fixed in RHEL 5/RHEL 6.  Here are the links I found:

* https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=683005
* https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=719435 (clone of https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=683005)
* http://rhn.redhat.com/errata/RHBA-2012-0248.html

I guess we probably just need to confirm that it has been fixed. In CentOS 6 and RHEL 6.  If not, we should open up a bug report.  Thoughts?

Implementation for EUCA-4786 fixes this bug to the extent that metadata service returns the block device mappings based on run instance and register image requests. This fix does NOT guarantee an exact match between the actual device mappings on the VM instance and those requested by the end user in run instance/register image requests (because of hypervisor limitations).

Added new eutester suite to test multiple block device mapping scenarios for ebs backed instances. The test executes a variety of maps set at registration time, run-time, and both reg+runtime. Each test run now includes a metadata check which iterates through the block device mapping and metadata service to compare. Please see attached eutester code and test log/output snippets. I think the one inconsistency is the reporting of ephemeral disk which is still being tracked in euca-6048. If the test is now passing so moving this ticket to resolved, but if it looks incomplete or incorrect please let me know. 
Thanks!
-Matt


{code}



###############################################################################################
###############################################################################################
From block device mapping test:
###############################################################################################
###############################################################################################
...
...
self.status('Check block device mapping meta data...')
meta_bdm = instance.block_device_mapping
  #Temp work around for existing bug where ephemeral is not reported...
  if not meta_bdm.has_key(bdm_ephemeral_dev):
    self.resulterr('Ephemeral disk not reported in instance block dev mapping: see euca-6048')
    meta_bdm[bdm_ephemeral_dev] = eph_dev
instance.check_instance_meta_data_for_block_device_mapping(root_dev=image.root_device_name, bdm=meta_bdm)
...
...

###############################################################################################
###############################################################################################
From euinstance class:
###############################################################################################
###############################################################################################
def check_instance_meta_data_for_block_device_mapping(self, root_dev=None, bdm=None):
        '''
        Checks current instances meta data against a provided block device map & root_dev, or
        against the current values of the instance; self.block_device_mapping & self.root_device_name
        '''
        self.tester.print_block_device_map(self.block_device_mapping)
        meta_dev_names = self.get_metadata('block-device-mapping')
        meta_devices = {}
        root_dev = root_dev or self.root_device_name
        orig_bdm = bdm or self.block_device_mapping
        bdm = copy.copy(orig_bdm)
        if root_dev in bdm:
            bdm.pop(root_dev)

        meta_ami = self.get_metadata('block-device-mapping/ami')
        if not root_dev in meta_ami:
            raise Exception('Meta data "block-device-mapping/ami":' + str(meta_ami) + ' != ' + str(root_dev))
        meta_dev_names.remove('ami')
        meta_emi = self.get_metadata('block-device-mapping/emi')
        if not root_dev in meta_emi :
            raise Exception('Meta data "block-device-mapping/emi":' + str(meta_emi) + ' != ' + str(root_dev))
        meta_dev_names.remove('emi')
        meta_root = self.get_metadata('block-device-mapping/root')
        if not root_dev in meta_root:
            raise Exception('Meta data "block-device-mapping/root":' + str(meta_root) + ' != ' + str(root_dev))
        meta_dev_names.remove('root')
        if self.root_device_type == 'ebs':
            meta_ebs1 = self.get_metadata('block-device-mapping/ebs1')
            if not root_dev in meta_ebs1:
                raise Exception('Meta data "block-device-mapping/ebs1":' + str(meta_ebs1) + ' != ' + str(root_dev))
            meta_dev_names.remove('ebs1')

        for device in meta_dev_names:
            meta_devices[device] =  self.get_metadata('block-device-mapping/' + str(device))[0]

        for device in bdm:
            found = False
            device_map = bdm[device]
            if device_map.no_device:
                continue
            else:
                if device_map.ephemeral_name:
                    dev_name_prefix = 'ephemeral'
                else:
                    dev_name_prefix = 'ebs'
                for meta_dev in meta_devices:
                    if str(meta_dev).startswith(dev_name_prefix):
                        if meta_devices.get(meta_dev) == device:
                            self.debug('Found meta data match for block device:' + str(device) + " at: " + str(meta_dev))
                            meta_devices.pop(meta_dev)
                            found = True
                            break
                if not found:
                    raise Exception('No meta data found for block dev map device:' + str(device))
        if meta_devices:
            err_buf = 'Unknown meta data found for the following not in:' + str(self.id) + "'s block_device_mapping:"
            for meta_dev in meta_devices:
                err_buf += "'" + str(meta_dev) + ":" + str(meta_devices.get(meta_dev)) + "', "
            raise Exception(err_buf)



###############################################################################################
###############################################################################################
Test output:

###############################################################################################
###############################################################################################

PING 169.254.169.254 (169.254.169.254) 56(84) bytes of data.
64 bytes from 169.254.169.254: icmp_seq=1 ttl=64 time=0.416 ms

--- 169.254.169.254 ping statistics ---
